Article.Abstract: Puumala virus (PUUV) is a hantavirus that causes hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS), which is an important public health problem in large parts of Europe. We examined the memory cytolytic T lymphocyte (CTL) responses in 13 Finnish individuals who had HFRS between 1984 and 1995. In seven of these donors, we detected virus-specific CTL responses against the PUUV nucleocapsid (N) protein after in vitro stimulation with PUUV. Six novel CD8(+) CTL epitopes were defined on the N protein and were found to be restricted by various HLA alleles including A2, A28, B7, and B8. This is the first demonstration of PUUV-specific CTL responses in humans, and the first identification of CTL epitopes on PUUV. In addition, this study provides one of the few characterizations of a human antiviral memory T cell response, without the complicating issues of virus persistence or reinfection. Interferon (IFN)-gamma ELISPOT analysis showed that memory CTL specific for these epitopes were present at high frequency in PUUV-immune individuals many years after acute infection in the absence of detectable viral RNA. The frequencies of PUUV-specific CTL were comparable to or exceeded those found in other viral systems including influenza, EBV and HIV, in which CTL responses may be boosted by periodic reinfection or virus persistence.
Article.ArticleTitle: Long-lived memory T lymphocyte responses after hantavirus infection.
Article.Affiliations: Center for Infectious Disease and Vaccine Research, University of Massachusetts Medical School, Worcester, MA 01655, USA.

Article.Comments: Data originally imported from the HLA Ligand Database (http://hlaligand.ouhsc.edu/)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Nine CTL lines isolated from a single donor recognized the epitope. The CTL lines specific for the epitope failed to recognize the N protein from either Hantaan virus or Sin Nombre virus. The sequences of these viral N proteins both differ from the Puumala virus sequence at this epitope by four amino acids, including a V to A change at the anchor position 9. The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Three CTL lines isolated from a single donor recognized the epitope. Of the two B7-restricted and one B8-restricted CTL lines that recognized Puumala virus N 173–81, only one displayed cross-reactive recognition of the Hantaan virus N protein. This epitope is well conserved among the viruses, with the Hantaan and Sin Nombre virus epitopes containing two conservative amino acid changes, and with both expressing the preferred P at position 2. The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Three CTL lines isolated from a single donor recognized the epitope. Of the two B7-restricted and one B8-restricted CTL lines that recognize Puumala virus N 173–81, only one displayed cross-reactive recognition of the Hantaan virus N protein. This epitope is well conserved among the viruses, with the Hantaan and Sin Nombre virus epitopes containing two conservative amino acid changes, and with both expressing the preferred P at position 2. The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

MhcAllele.MhcEvidenceCode: T cell assay -T cell subset identification

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Seven CTL lines isolated from a single donor were shown to recognize the epitope. All but one of the CTL lines specific for the epitope failed to recognize the N protein from either Hantaan virus or Sin Nombre virus. One CTL line consistently recognized targets expressing the Sin Nombre virus N protein as well as those expressing the Puumala virus N protein. The sequence at this epitope is extremely variable among different hantaviruses. The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

MhcAllele.MhcEvidenceCode: T cell assay -T cell subset identification

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Two CTL lines isolated from a single donor were shown to recognize the epitope. Both of the CTL lines specific for the epitope failed to recognize the N protein from either Hantaan virus or Sin Nombre virus, despite a high level of sequence conservation at this epitope. The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: One CTL line isolated from a single donor recognized the epitope. This CTL line was crossreactive with the Hantavirus N protein, but did not recognizethe Sin Nombre N protein. This epitope is relatively well conserved between Puumala virus and Hantavirus, with the corresponding epitope on Hantavirus N differing by three amino acids and less well conserved between Puumala virus and Sin Nombre virus, which differ by six amino acids at this epitope. The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were Finnish individuals who had hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome caused by Puumala virus infection between the years 1984 and 1995.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The restricting HLA alleles required for peptide recognition by these CTL lines was determined using a panel of partially HLA-matched BLCLs as targets in 51 [Cr] release assays.
